Show thinking

Understood, Lan. I will embody Bam and Anna's characters as you journey towards Wyvern Tor.

The path out of Phandalin gradually becomes less defined, merging with the rugged terrain. The air grows cooler as you gain elevation, and the scent of pine trees mingles with the earthy smell of the wilderness. Lan, you move ahead, a silent shadow, your senses sharp, attuned to the subtle sounds and movements of the wilds.

Behind you, Bjorn walks with a heavy tread, his boots occasionally scuffing loudly on loose rocks. He hums a tuneless ditty under his breath, occasionally pausing to peer intently into the trees as if daring an orc to show its face already.

Bam (as Bjorn): "Hoo boy, this is the life! Fresh air, the promise of a good scrap... beats sitting around in that dusty town any day! Though, I gotta admit," he lowers his voice slightly, leaning a bit towards Elara, "Lan's really quiet when he gets like this. Almost unnervin'. Like a... a really deadly mouse, I guess? Can't even hear him! Good thing one of us makes enough noise for three people, eh?" He grins, slapping his thigh. "Think orcs smell bad, Elara? Like, worse than goblins? Goblins smell like damp dog and old socks."

Elara walks with her hands clasped loosely behind her back, her eyes sweeping across the landscape, noting the type of trees, the rock formations, the flight patterns of birds. She considers Bjorn's question for a moment, a faint, almost imperceptible smile touching her lips at the "deadly mouse" comparison.

Anna (as Elara): "Orcs, Bjorn, are generally described as having a strong, musky odor, often associated with damp earth and aggression. More akin to a cornered boar, perhaps, than domestic canids." She pauses, then adds dryly, "And while Lan's 'stealth' may lack your... sonorous quality, it tends to be rather more effective in avoiding unwelcome attention. Something we should perhaps appreciate until the moment calls for direct, loud, and impactful action." She adjusts a small bag on her belt. "My texts mention orcs favoring crude but effective ambush tactics. Caves, narrow passes... places where numbers can overwhelm skill. Lan's caution is well-placed."

Bjorn scratches his beard thoughtfully.

Bam (as Bjorn): "Heh, 'sonorous quality.' You make my footsteps sound fancy, Elara. And yeah, I guess sneaking's alright before the fight. Just... hope they don't make us wait too long. My smashing arm is getting impatient!" He gives 'Ol Smashy another little pat.

The sun climbs higher in the sky as you continue your journey. The terrain is becoming more challenging, the path less clear.

Lan, you're leading the way, setting the pace. What do you observe about the changing landscape or any signs of the Orcs? How do you respond to Bjorn and Elara's conversation?

Understood. I will now roleplay as both Bjorn and Elara as you lead the way towards Wyvern Tor.

You focus your senses, Lan, letting your rogue's training take over. Your eyes flick across the details of the path – scuff marks on stones, bent blades of grass, disturbed pebbles. You listen intently to the sounds of the wilderness, trying to discern anything out of the ordinary buried within the chirping of insects and the calls of distant birds. The wind carries the scent of pine and damp earth, but nothing immediately reeks of unwashed orc.

The terrain becomes rockier, the path occasionally forcing you to navigate around larger stones or patches of dense, thorny bushes. You haven't spotted any obvious trails of a large group, no carelessly broken branches or discarded scraps that would immediately scream "Orcs were here!" It's possible they're keeping to higher ground, or perhaps they are simply more careful than the goblins you've encountered.

Behind you, Bjorn sighs dramatically.

Bam (as Bjorn): "Anything, Lan? See any green skins just... waiting to be introduced to Ol' Smashy?" He shifts his weight, the chain mail making a soft clinking sound. "This walking bit is alright, but it's much better when there's something to chase! Or something chasing us! Adds a bit of spice, eh?" He looks back towards Phandalin, now a faint smudge against the horizon. "Least the ale was good back there..."

Elara shakes her head slightly at Bjorn's impatience. She's walking a little closer to him now, her eyes still scanning the environment, but also occasionally glancing towards you, assessing your progress and observations.

Anna (as Elara): "Patience, Bjorn. Detecting danger is not always about seeing a horde directly in front of you. Lan is looking for signs, for subtle disruptions in the natural order that might indicate a presence." She frowns slightly, then looks towards the distant, jagged peaks. "Wyvern Tor is a formidable place. The orcs likely choose it for its defensible position and difficult terrain. Finding their lair will require more than simply following a well-trodden path." She adjusts her glasses. "My studies indicate orcs often mark their territory, though the methods can vary widely between tribes. Look for crude symbols carved into trees or rocks, unusual cairns, or perhaps... less pleasant signs." She shivers inwardly at the thought.

The sun continues its arc across the sky. The landscape is growing more wild, the air thinner and cooler. You are definitely heading into less hospitable territory.

Lan, you've been scanning the area. What specifically are you looking for? Do you see anything that catches your expert eye, however subtle? And how do you respond to your companions?

Sources and related content

Look for any blood, animal carcass, and sign of battle on the road ahead

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

You continue your focused scan of the trail and the areas immediately surrounding it. Your eyes, trained to spot the minutiae others miss, scrutinize the packed earth, the undersides of leaves, the crevices between rocks. You're looking for anything that disrupts the natural patterns of the wilderness – a splatter of dark, dried blood that isn't from a wounded deer, bones gnawed by something larger and more deliberate than local predators, or the tell-tale gouges and scattered debris that signal a violent confrontation.

The path winds through increasing rocky terrain. The air grows cooler, hinting at the higher altitudes ahead. For a while, you find nothing significant. The forest floor shows signs of typical wilderness life – tracks of small animals, fallen branches, scattered feathers – but no grim evidence of recent orc activity.

Suddenly, something catches your eye near a cluster of larger boulders off to the side of the path. A patch of earth seems slightly disturbed, and a few stones are out of place. Kneeling closer, you examine the area. There's no obvious blood or carcass, but the disturbance isn't entirely natural. It looks... deliberate, but not fresh. Perhaps from something heavy being dragged, or a brief, contained struggle. There's a faint, almost imperceptible dark stain on one of the rocks, too small to be conclusive, but it could be old, dried blood.

Anna (as Elara): "Anything, Lan?" Elara's voice is quiet, observant, as she watches you investigate the spot. "Did you find something?"

Bjorn, meanwhile, has paused, leaning on 'Ol Smashy like a massive, impatient statue.

Bam (as Bjorn): "Ooh, secrets! Did he find something secret? Is it gold? Please say it's gold. Or maybe just a really shiny rock? Orcs like shiny things, right?"

Lan, you've found a subtle sign. What do you make of it? How do you describe it to your companions, or do you keep it to yourself for a moment?

Sources and related content

We seems to be near orc activity. There is a sign of an animal being dragged away. This, however, is already too old, so i can't be too sure. But we still have to remain vigilant.

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

Your expression is serious as you relay your findings. "Something was dragged here, definitely. Large. And maybe there was... a struggle, or a kill." You gesture to the disturbed earth and the faint stain. "It's not fresh, though. Days old, maybe. Hard to tell exactly, the wilderness reclaims things quickly. But it's a sign. We're in the right area, I think. Or getting close." You look towards the increasingly rugged terrain leading towards the mountains. "Just means we need to be extra careful from here on out."

Bjorn's earlier impatience seems to melt away, replaced by a more focused intensity. He straightens up, his hand instinctively resting on the hilt of 'Ol Smashy.

Bam (as Bjorn): "Days old, huh? Missed the party, then." He lets out a low growl, more serious than his previous jokes. "Doesn't matter. If they were here, their friends probably aren't far off. Good. Means we're on the right track." He scans the surrounding trees and rocks, his gaze no longer casual but searching, assessing potential ambush points. "Alright, Lan. Lead the way. Just give us a sign if you see anything fresh, yeah? Anything that needs... persuadin'." He flexes his fingers on his sword hilt.

Elara nods, her expression mirroring your own vigilance. She looks from the disturbed ground to the path ahead, her eyes narrowing slightly.

Anna (as Elara): "An animal, or perhaps... something else? Orcs are known to take captives, or hunt larger game than this area might typically support naturally." She considers this, then looks towards the slopes of Wyvern Tor. "Old signs are better than no signs, I suppose. It confirms our direction is correct. But as Lan says, vigilance is paramount. A skilled group of orcs would know how to use this terrain to their advantage for an ambush. We should assume they are watching." She subtly adjusts the position of her component pouch, her mind clearly already anticipating the potential need for spells.

The air feels different now, perhaps just the power of suggestion, but the woods seem quieter, the shadows deeper. You continue your trek, the slight uphill climb becoming more noticeable. The terrain is more broken, with more places for creatures to hide.

Lan, your keen senses are on high alert. You've found your first solid, though old, sign of the orcs' presence. How do you lead the party now? Are there any specific features of the landscape you focus on, or any particular precautions you emphasize as you move deeper into what is clearly becoming Orc territory?

Sources and related content

Wait. Let me scout ahead. Stealthily.

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

Ah, a wise move, Lan. A rogue's greatest weapon isn't always their blade, but their silence.

You signal to Elara and Bjorn, a quick, almost imperceptible hand gesture that means "hold here, and keep quiet." They nod in understanding, immediately slowing their pace and stepping off the main line of the trail, seeking cover behind some thick brush and rocks. Bjorn, for once, manages to shift his weight with surprising quiet, his usual boisterous energy reigned in. Elara, ever perceptive, seems to melt into the natural cover, her gaze fixed on you as you prepare to move.

Taking a deep breath, you focus your senses, becoming one with the rustling leaves and whispering wind. You analyze the terrain ahead – the patches of loose scree that might shift underfoot, the dry twigs that could snap, the areas of dense shadow that offer concealment. You move with deliberate care, each step measured, your weight distributed to minimize sound. Your eyes dart from potential cover to potential threat, scanning the rocky slopes and thickets for any sign of movement or unnatural stillness.

As you slip forward, you attempt to blend into the natural sounds and sights of the wilderness.

Taking point and moving stealthily in this environment, especially with the potential for orc lookouts, requires a Dexterity (Stealth) check. Let's set the DC for this section of the wilderness at DC 14.

Please make a Dexterity (Stealth) check. Your proficiency bonus is +2. Add your Dexterity modifier to the roll.

Roll the die. What is your result?

Okay, you hold your position, your eyes meticulously scanning the rugged terrain ahead from your vantage point. You sweep your gaze across the narrow defile, the rocky slopes, the thickets of gnarled bushes – anywhere an orc might conceal themselves. You listen to the wind, trying to filter out natural sounds from anything that might indicate a hidden presence.

Rolling 1d20 + 3 for Wisdom (Perception)...

The die tumbles, and your result is 13.

Your Perception check is a good effort, but the wilderness is vast and full of natural concealment. While your gaze is sharp, and you take in the details of the rocky landscape – the way the shadows fall, the sparse vegetation clinging to the stone – you don't spot any obvious movement or figures lurking in the immediate area. The orcs, if they are present and watching, are doing a good job of remaining hidden within their chosen territory.

You don't see any patrols or lookouts in plain sight from your current position. The metallic scent of blood is strongest near the disturbed ground you already investigated, fading as you look further ahead.

Behind you, you can sense the patient stillness of Elara and the barely contained eagerness of Bjorn, waiting for your signal. The wind whispers through the rocks around you, carrying no distinct sounds of orcish activity from further up the slopes.

Sources and related content

Scan from different vantage point.

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

You carefully move from your current cover, utilizing the rocky terrain to your advantage. Your successful Stealth check means you reach a new position unnoticed. You find a slightly elevated spot, perhaps behind a taller boulder or a cluster of thick, low-lying bushes, that offers a broader view of the path ahead and the slopes rising towards Wyvern Tor.

From this new vantage point, the landscape unfolds a little more clearly. The path continues its winding ascent, disappearing around a bend in the rock face further ahead. The slopes around the path are steep and littered with scree and jagged stones, offering numerous nooks and crannies for concealment. The air here is cooler still, carrying the scent of mountain herbs and damp stone, along with that faint, lingering smell of blood from the area you previously noted.

You settle into your new position, eyes narrowed, meticulously sweeping the terrain within your sight. You're looking for any shape that seems out of place, any glint of metal, any subtle shift in the shadows that isn't caused by the wind.

Rolling 1d20 + 3 for Wisdom (Perception) from the new vantage point...

The die settles, and your total is 18.

Success! From this elevated position, your keen rogue's eyes pick out something others might miss. High up on the rocky slope to the east of the path, almost perfectly blended with the stone, you spot movement. It's subtle, just a flicker, but unmistakable. Focusing your gaze, you discern figures – hulking, green-skinned shapes. They are nestled among the rocks, using the natural terrain for cover, their crude armor and weapons blending with the stone.

You count three orcs, positioned to observe the path below. They appear to be a lookout or a small patrol, keeping watch over the approach to whatever lies further within Wyvern Tor. They are relatively still, clearly trying to remain unseen, and their passive perception would likely be around 10. Your Stealth has kept you hidden from them for now.

You have located a hostile force. They are approximately a couple hundred feet away, positioned on the slope.

Lan, you have successfully spotted an orc lookout. What is your next move? Do you observe them further? Try to determine their patrol pattern? Signal back to Elara and Bjorn? Fall back? The choice is yours.

Sources and related content

Inform the others about this. And discuss about a plan to take them out

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

Okay, you carefully adjust your position behind the boulder, making sure you're still well-concealed. You consider the distance and the need for a coherent plan. Signaling from here might be too risky, potentially drawing attention. Slipping back to the others seems the most prudent course.

With the same practiced quiet that brought you here, you begin to backtrack, your senses still sharp for any sign that the orcs might have spotted your initial movement. The rocky ground offers challenges, but your previous successful stealth allows you to move with confidence.

You reach the spot where you left Elara and Bjorn. They are still patiently waiting, their eyes fixed in the direction you went. Bjorn looks ready to spring, while Elara's expression is a mix of concern and anticipation. As you emerge from cover, they turn to you, relief and expectation on their faces.

Bam (as Bjorn): "Lan! Took you long enough! Everything alright? See any green skins?" His voice is a low rumble, mindful of their hidden position.

Anna (as Elara): Elara gives a small, relieved nod as you appear. "Lan. Report. What did you find?" Her gaze is intense, awaiting your information.

You quickly and quietly relay what you saw: the three orcs, their position high on the slope, and the fresher sign of dragging near the path.

"They're a lookout, I think," you murmur, keeping your voice low. "Three of them, up on the slope to the east of the path. Blending in well, but I spotted their movement. There's also newer signs of something dragged, closer to the path than before, and the smell of blood." You pause, looking towards the slope where you saw them. "They're watching the approach. We need to take them out before we move further in, or they'll raise the alarm."

You look at your companions, the unspoken question hanging in the air: How do we do this?

Bjorn's eyes gleam at the mention of orcs, his hand tightening on 'Ol Smashy's hilt, but he looks to you, acknowledging your lead in this situation.

Bam (as Bjorn): "Three, eh? Sounds like a warm-up! Just point me at 'em, Lan. Ol' Smashy is eager to make some introductions!"

Elara is already contemplating the information, her brow furrowed in thought. She glances at the slope, then back at the path.

Anna (as Elara): "Three on a slope... that gives them a height advantage, and cover. A direct assault might be costly." She taps a finger against her chin. "Magic could work, but we'd need to be careful about line of sight and alerting others if there's a larger group nearby." She looks from you to Bjorn. "Lan, you're the expert at getting in close unseen. Bjorn, your strength... perhaps a combination? Distraction? A pincer?"

The discussion has begun. You have the target: three orcs on a slope. You have the objective: take them out quietly.

What are your thoughts, Lan? How do you want to approach this? What's the plan?

Sources and related content

Elara, how many people can you make invisible with your invisibility spell?

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

Anna (as Elara): Elara considers your question, her hand going to her component pouch for a moment as she thinks about the arcane energies involved. "The Invisibility spell I know... the standard version..." She pauses, choosing her words carefully. "It can make one creature invisible. Just one. It's not a spell for concealing a whole group, not at this level."

She looks from you to Bjorn, the implication clear. One of you could become invisible, or perhaps a distraction could be made invisible, but not everyone for a full assault.

The planning continues. You know the target, you know their general location and numbers (three orcs), and you have some tools available. The terrain is against a direct approach.

What is the strategy, Lan? How will you use the information you've gathered and the limited magical resources you have to deal with this lookout?

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

Okay, a plan is forming! Using Elara's magic to get Bjorn in position for a surprise strike, while you and Elara follow up with an ambush. It leverages your strengths.

Elara considers the idea, nodding slowly as you explain.

Anna (as Elara): "Making Bjorn invisible..." She looks at Bjorn, then back at you. "Yes, that is possible with the spell. I can touch him, and he will become unseen." She holds up a finger, a thoughtful expression on her face. "However, my Invisibility requires my concentration. And, crucially, the spell ends on the target the moment they attack or cast a spell. So, Bjorn would be invisible getting into position, but the moment he swings 'Ol Smashy, he'll reappear." She looks at the slope where you saw the orcs. "Getting into position unseen is the key for him. For you and me to sneak up behind him... that will require our own skills in stealth, as the spell only affects the target I touch."

Bjorn's eyes light up at the prospect of being invisible, picturing the element of surprise.

Bam (as Bjorn): "Invisible smashing! I like it!" He chuckles quietly. "So I sneak up like a big, green-skinned ghost, pick my orc, and then WHAM! Ol' Smashy makes an entrance! While they're surprised, you two jump in? Sounds like a good scrap!" He flexes his considerable muscles. "I'll be quiet as a church mouse, promise! A very large, heavily armed church mouse."

Alright, the framework is there. Elara makes Bjorn invisible. You and Elara follow stealthily. Bjorn gets into position to attack one orc. When he attacks (breaking invisibility), you and Elara initiate your ambush on the remaining two.

Now, let's refine this.

  1. The Approach: While Bjorn is invisible, you and Elara will need to move stealthily yourselves to keep pace and get into position for the ambush. Rocky slopes and sparse cover make this challenging. Your own Stealth skills will be crucial, and Elara is... less naturally inclined towards silent movement than you. How do you coordinate this? Do you move together, or do you range slightly ahead to guide her?
  2. Bjorn's Target and Position: Which orc does Bjorn target? And where does he position himself exactly? Will he be able to get close enough for a melee attack without being heard before the strike, even if invisible? The slope could work for or against him.
  3. The Ambush Trigger: The plan hinges on Bjorn's first strike. How quickly can you and Elara react and close the distance once he engages? Are you in position to immediately attack the other two orcs?
  4. Elara's Role in the Ambush: What is Elara's planned action once the ambush is triggered? A spell? A ranged attack?

Think about the details, Lan. This is a good plan, but the execution in this terrain against watchful orcs will require precision. What are your thoughts on these points?

Sources and related content

I will move and traverse close enough to one of the orc, Elara, perhaps you should hide and prepare for a ranged spell. Once Bjorn is in position, we'll give them everything we got.

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

Your plan is set. You explain the coordinated approach to Elara and Bjorn. Elara nods, her gaze focused, already picturing the weave of the spell. Bjorn flexes his hands, a determined glint in his eye.

"Alright," Elara says softly, her voice barely above a whisper. "Stand still, Bjorn."

She reaches out and touches Bjorn's arm, speaking the mystical words and performing the subtle somatic gestures of the spell. For a moment, the air around Bjorn shimmers, distorting like heat haze, and then he simply... vanishes. The space he occupied seems empty, save for a faint ripple in the air where he stands.

Anna (as Elara): "He is invisible," she confirms, her voice low. "Remember, my concentration is required. If I am harmed, or if my focus is broken, the spell will end prematurely. And the moment Bjorn attacks, the magic on him will cease." She takes a deep breath, maintaining her concentration.

Bjorn gives a silent thumbs-up, a nearly invisible gesture in the empty air. He adjusts his grip on 'Ol Smashy, the faint sound of leather on metal almost swallowed by the ambient noise of the wilderness. He begins to move with surprising grace for his size, a shimmering distortion moving slowly towards the slope you indicated.

Now it's your turn, Lan. You and Elara need to move into position while Bjorn makes his silent approach. The terrain is still challenging, and the orcs are watchful.

Rolling 1d20 + 5 for Lan's Stealth... Rolling 1d20 + 2 for Elara's Stealth...

Your die result is 16 for Stealth. Elara's result is 9.

You move with practiced skill, using every available rock and bush for cover, your steps light and precise. You are a shadow, easily keeping yourself from being seen. However, Elara, while attempting to be quiet, is not a rogue. Her movements, though deliberate, are occasionally accompanied by the faint scrape of boot on stone or the rustle of her robes against the brush. She tries her best to follow your lead and stay low, but it's a struggle for her in this environment.

Despite Elara's less-than-perfect stealth, your superior movement and guidance manage to prevent her from making truly obvious noise for the moment. You don't hear any shouts or alarms from the direction of the orcs.

You lead Elara towards a cluster of rocks and thicket that should provide her with cover and a clear line of sight to the orc lookout's position.

Anna (as Elara): Elara reaches the cover you indicated, sinking down behind the rocks with a relieved sigh that she quickly stifles. She takes a moment to adjust her position, then begins to prepare a spell, her hands moving in silent, practiced gestures as she focuses her arcane energy. The air around her crackles faintly, though it's hidden by her cover. "I am ready," she whispers.

You then move into your own chosen position, utilizing the terrain to get relatively close to where one of the orcs is stationed, ensuring you have cover but also a clear line of sight for an attack.

The tension in the air is thick. Bjorn, invisible, is maneuvering into his striking position. Elara is hidden, a spell crackling at her fingertips. You are poised, ready to strike.

You wait, listening, your eyes fixed on the slope where you know the orcs are. The seconds stretch into a minute. You see the faint shimmer of Bjorn's approach as he nears his target, a barely visible distortion against the rocky background.

Then, with a sudden, brutal efficiency, the shimmer around Bjorn vanishes as 'Ol Smashy arcs through the air. The sharp crack of metal on bone, followed by a guttural cry of pain and surprise, shatters the wilderness quiet!

Ambush!

The two remaining orcs on the slope react instantly, turning towards their fallen comrade, their faces contorted in shock and rage.

Initiative! Roll initiative for the party and the orcs. I will roll for the orcs.

Rolling 1d20 for Orc Initiative...

Orc Initiative: 11.

Now, roll initiative for yourself, Elara, and Bjorn. Add your Dexterity modifiers. Elara's initiative is based on her Dexterity, Bjorn's on his, and yours on your high Dexterity. What are your results?

Sources and related content

Roll!

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

Rolling 1d20 + 3 for Lan's Initiative... Rolling 1d20 + 2 for Elara's Initiative... Rolling 1d20 + 1 for Bjorn's Initiative...

Okay, the dice are cast!

Lan's Initiative: 19 (+3 Dex) = 22 Elara's Initiative: 8 (+2 Dex) = 10 Bjorn's Initiative: 14 (+1 Dex) = 15 Orcs' Initiative: 11

The initiative order is:

  1. Lan (22)
  2. Bjorn (15)
  3. Orcs (11)
  4. Elara (10)

You are first, Lan! Bjorn's sudden attack has thrown the orcs into disarray, and you are perfectly positioned, hidden near one of them, while Elara is hunkered down with a spell ready. The element of surprise, at least for the initial strike, is in your favor.

The two remaining orcs are reacting to their fallen comrade, momentarily stunned by the swiftness of Bjorn's blow. The orc nearest to you is still looking towards the spot where his companion just fell, his crude orcish features twisting in shock.

What is your action, Lan, at the start of combat? You are hidden.

Sources and related content

Alright, target the closest orc, and pierce his neck with rapier

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

With your initiative of 22, you burst into action as the chaos erupts! The orc closest to you is still reeling from the shock of seeing his comrade fall to an unseen foe, his attention momentarily diverted. This is your chance.

You dart from your cover, rapier flashing, aiming for a vital strike.

Rolling 1d20 with Advantage for Attack... (Rolling two d20s and taking the higher result) Your two attack dice are 18 and 7. You take the 18. Your Attack Roll: 18 (+3 Dex + +2 Prof) = 23

Your strike is swift and true! The attack roll of 23 easily beats the orc's AC of 13. You plunge your rapier into the orc's neck, the keen blade finding its mark.

Now for damage! You hit, and since you were hidden, you get Sneak Attack damage.

Rolling 1d8 piercing damage for Rapier... Rolling 2d6 Sneak Attack damage...

Rapier Damage: 6 Sneak Attack Damage: 4 + 5 = 9

Total Damage: 6 (Rapier) + 3 (Dex Modifier) + 9 (Sneak Attack) = 18 piercing damage.

Your rapier bites deep, a brutal, precise strike to the neck. The orc gurgles, its eyes wide with surprise and pain, before collapsing to the rocky ground, lifeless.

Your position is no longer a secret. You stand over the fallen orc, rapier still in hand, having just revealed yourself.

Your turn is complete. Next in the initiative order is Bjorn!

Bam (as Bjorn): From his invisible position near the fallen orc, a fierce roar erupts as Bjorn becomes visible, already swinging 'Ol Smashy!

What does Bjorn do on his turn? He is now visible, standing near the two surviving orcs.

Okay, it's Bjorn's turn! His invisible approach shattered, he roars and swings 'Ol Smashy at the closest remaining orc.

Rolling 1d20 + 6 for Bjorn's Attack... The die spins and lands on... 19!

A natural 19! As a Champion Fighter, that's a critical hit! Bjorn's blow is devastating!

Now for the damage, rolling double dice for the critical hit!

Rolling 4d6 slashing damage (2d6 doubled) + 4 Strength modifier...

Damage Dice: 5 + 3 + 6 + 2 = 16 Total Damage: 16 (4d6) + 4 (Strength) = 20 slashing damage.

Bjorn's greatsword cleaves through the orc with brutal force. 'Ol Smashy lives up to its name, delivering a massive blow that sends the orc tumbling from its perch on the slope, a ragged cry cut short as it falls.

With two orcs down, only one remains!

It is now the Orcs' turn (Initiative 11). One orc is left on the slope. It has seen its two companions fall in a matter of seconds to seemingly invisible or unseen attackers. It's enraged and panicked.

The remaining orc's eyes dart between the spot where Bjorn just appeared and your now-revealed position near where the first orc fell. It lets out a guttural roar of challenge and fury.

What does the remaining orc do? It will likely target the closest visible threat, which is you, Lan.

Rolling 1d20 + 5 for the Orc's Greataxe attack...

The die result is 8. Orc's Attack Roll: 8 (+5 Attack Bonus) = 13.

The orc's greataxe swings wildly in its rage, but your Armor Class is higher than 13. The blow goes wide, perhaps hitting the rocks near you, sending sparks flying.

The orc missed!

That concludes the Orcs' turn. Next in the initiative order is Elara (Initiative 10). She is hidden behind rocks, having prepared a ranged spell.

What does Elara do on her turn?

Show thinking

You are absolutely correct, Lan! My apologies. You struck down one orc, and Bjorn, with a mighty critical hit, felled a second.

There were three orcs in that lookout group. With two down, that means none of that initial group remain standing on the slope.

The immediate threat from this specific lookout is neutralized. However, the sounds of the ambush – Bjorn's roar, the thud of the fallen orcs, the clash of steel – would definitely carry in the relative quiet of the wilderness.

It is indeed Elara's turn (Initiative 10). She is still hidden behind the rocks, a spell ready. The last thing she heard was the sounds of a very successful, very loud, ambush concluding.

Elara, seeing the two orcs fall and hearing the sudden silence of their demise, eases her readied spell, though she doesn't dismiss the magical energy entirely. She peeks cautiously from behind her cover, her sharp elven eyes scanning the slope and the area beyond where the orcs were positioned.

Anna (as Elara): "Two down," she murmurs, a hint of surprise and relief in her voice. She quickly scans the area. "But that... was rather loud. We should anticipate company." She looks further up the slopes towards the unseen parts of Wyvern Tor, her expression now one of alert caution.

What does Elara do on her turn, now that the immediate orcs are dealt with, but more threats are likely? Does she move, try to hide better, prepare a different spell, or focus on listening?

Sources and related content

Elara focus on listening

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

Anna (as Elara): Elara's eyes are closed for a moment, her brow furrowed in concentration as she focuses her hearing. The sounds of the wilderness seem to sharpen around her – the distant cry of a hawk, the rustle of leaves, the scuttling of small creatures in the undergrowth. She strains to pick out anything else, anything unnatural, over the fading echoes of the recent, violent confrontation.

Rolling 1d20 + 4 for Elara's Wisdom (Perception) [Listening]...

Her die result is 16.

Elara's elven senses, honed by her focus, pick up something faint but distinct. It's a rhythmic clink... scrape... clink... scrape from further up the slopes, accompanied by occasional low grunts and the shifting of loose rock. It's not the natural sounds of the mountains. It's the sound of heavy, armored movement, and it's heading in your direction. It's still some distance off, perhaps a few hundred feet, but they are definitely approaching, likely drawn by the sounds of the fight.

Anna (as Elara): Elara's eyes snap open, her expression grim. She keeps her voice low, urgent. "Company. Moving this way. Sounds like... more orcs. Several of them, I think. They heard us."

The first round of combat is over. You successfully eliminated two of the lookouts, but the fight was not silent, and the enemy is responding.

It is now the start of the second round. Lan, you are first in the initiative order (22). Bjorn (15) is positioned near the fallen orcs, Elara (10) is in cover, having heard the approaching reinforcements, and the approaching orcs have Initiative 11.

The immediate area is clear of the initial three orcs, but new threats are on their way, though not yet visible. What do you do?

Scatter caltrops at possible path that the orcs appear!

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

Lan, with swift, practiced movements, you reach into your gear and pull out a bag of caltrops. Your eyes are already fixed on the area below the orc lookout's position – the narrowest part of the path leading up the slope is the most likely route for reinforcements.

As your action, you scatter the sharp metal spikes across a 5-foot square section of the path below. They clatter lightly on the rocks, blending somewhat with the natural debris of the slope.

You are no longer hidden after performing this action.

Your turn is complete. Next in the initiative order is Bjorn (15). He is near the fallen orcs, ready for action.

Bam (as Bjorn): Seeing you deploy the caltrops, Bjorn gives a grim nod of understanding. "Good thinking, Lan! Slow 'em down!" He tightens his grip on 'Ol Smashy, glancing towards the direction Elara indicated the reinforcements are coming from.

What does Bjorn do on his turn? He is still visible from his previous attack.

Try to reposition and prepare to attack the orc the moment it appears!

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Show thinking

It's Bjorn's turn, and he repositions, moving with surprising agility for his size, using some of the larger rocks on the slope for partial cover. He lifts 'Ol Smashy, holding the massive blade ready, his eyes fixed on the area where Elara heard the approaching orcs. He's a coiled spring of anticipation, waiting for the perfect moment to strike.

Bam (as Bjorn): His voice is a low growl of anticipation. "Come on, you green-skinned brutes! Let's see what you've got!"

Now it's the Orcs' turn (Initiative 11). Drawn by the sounds of the fight, a new group of orcs is moving into the area. Elara heard them approaching from the east slope.

The approaching orcs, likely alerted by the commotion and now possibly seeing their fallen comrades or you and Bjorn's exposed positions, are moving towards the site of the ambush. They aren't being as cautious as a scouting party might normally be, their initial shock and rage outweighing their usual tactical sense.

Rolling for Orc movement and potential caltrop interaction...

Three orcs, likely from a larger patrol, emerge from behind a cluster of rocks further up the slope, heading down towards the scene of the conflict. They spot the fallen orcs, and then their eyes fall on you and Bjorn.

One of the orcs barrels forward, moving directly towards the narrow section of the path where you scattered the caltrops.

Rolling Dexterity Saving Throw vs DC 15 for the lead Orc entering the caltrops...

The die result is 6.

The orc, caught up in its charge, doesn't see the scattered caltrops until it's too late. Its heavy boot lands squarely on the sharp spikes.

The orc cries out in pain and surprise, stumbling. It stops moving, a single caltrop embedding itself in its foot. Its movement is halted, and its speed is reduced.

The other two orcs in the group, seeing their companion stumble and likely spotting the caltrops, become more cautious. They slow their pace, spreading out slightly on the slope, assessing the situation. They haven't reached the caltrops yet, but they are now aware of the hazard.

The lead orc is stuck in the caltrops. The other two are approaching cautiously. Bjorn's readied action is triggered by the appearance of the orcs. He can now make his attack!

Bam (as Bjorn): "Aha! Got one!" Bjorn bellows as the orc yelps in pain, swinging 'Ol Smashy with renewed vigor at the injured orc in the caltrops.

Rolling 1d20 + 6 for Bjorn's readied Attack...

The die result is 14.

Bjorn's attack roll of 14 hits the orc's AC of 13!

Now for damage!

Rolling 2d6 slashing damage + 4 Strength modifier...

Damage Dice: 3 + 5 = 8 Total Damage: 8 (2d6) + 4 (Strength) = 12 slashing damage.

Bjorn's greatsword bites into the orc, but it remains standing, though clearly wounded and still hobbled by the caltrop. Bjorn has used his reaction to make this attack.

That concludes the Orcs' turn and Bjorn's reaction. It is now Elara's turn (Initiative 10). She is hidden and has heard the approaching orcs.

What does Elara do?

Round 2 begins now! Lan, you are first (22), followed by Bjorn (15), the Orcs (11), and Elara (10).

The situation: One orc is down (killed by you). One orc is wounded and stuck in caltrops (hit by Bjorn twice). Two more orcs are approaching cautiously on the slope (unharmed). You are no longer hidden. Bjorn is not hidden. Elara is hidden.

Lan, it's your turn! What do you do?

I shoot with a shortbow toward one of the orcs.

Okay, Lan, it's your turn, and you're choosing to engage the approaching orcs with your shortbow. Since the orcs Elara heard are still some distance away and not visible from your current position near the fallen orcs, you'll need to move to get a clear shot.

You quickly move from your spot, heading towards a position that offers a better view up the slope where the reinforcements were heard. This movement takes you out from behind cover, leaving you exposed on the rocky terrain.

As you reach a point where you have a clear line of sight to the approaching orcs, you nock an arrow, draw your shortbow, and take aim at one of the two unscathed orcs.

Ah, my apologies! You are absolutely right, Lan. I got ahead of myself in the excitement of the ambush!

  1. Lan (22) - Took down the first orc.
  2. Bjorn (15) - Took down the second orc.

Anna (as Elara): Elara remains still, her head tilted slightly as she concentrates on the sounds of the wilderness, trying to pinpoint the location and number of the approaching threats.

Rolling 1d20 + 4 for Elara's Wisdom (Perception) [Listening]...

Her die result is 16.

Elara's keen hearing pierces through the natural sounds of the mountain. She can clearly distinguish the heavy, uneven tread of orcish boots on stone and scree. There are indeed multiple sets of footsteps, accompanied by the occasional clink of armor or weapon. She estimates there are at least three, possibly four, orcs in the approaching group, and they are moving with purpose towards the site of the recent commotion.   1. Lan (22)
  2. Bjorn (15)
  3. Orcs (11) (The two approaching orcs, and the one stuck in caltrops, though that one is severely hindered)
  4. Elara (10)

I want to test your memory. What is the latest situation of the party?

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Analysis

Analysis

Read documents

Response finalized

Okay, adventurer, let's get you up to speed on the latest situation!

Current Situation: Ambush at Wyvern Tor!

You are currently in the midst of a fierce battle against orcs at Wyvern Tor. The fight has just entered its second round.

Here's a quick rundown of the current state of affairs:

  • Location: The rocky slopes leading towards Wyvern Tor.
  • Party Status: 
  • Lan (You): Initiative 22. You are no longer hidden. It is currently your turn to act!
  • Bjorn Stonehand: Initiative 15. He is no longer hidden and is positioned near where the initial orc lookouts fell.
  • Elara Meadowlight: Initiative 10. She is currently hidden and has detected more orcs approaching.
  • Enemy Status: 
  • Two of the initial orc lookouts have been defeated (one by you, one by Bjorn).
  • Reinforcements have arrived!
  • One orc from this new group is stuck in your caltrops and wounded (after being hit by Bjorn's readied attack).
  • Elara has heard at least two more orcs approaching. They are not yet visible but are moving towards your position, drawn by the sounds of combat.
  • Initiative Order for Round 2: 
  1. Lan (You) 
  2. Bjorn
  3. Orcs (including the approaching ones and the one in caltrops)
  4. Elara

The immediate area around where the lookouts were stationed is clear of those initial threats, but the noise of your successful ambush has drawn more orcs. Elara's keen hearing has warned you of at least two, possibly more, heading your way.

It is your turn, Lan! What do you do?

Sources

Alright. I will use my charger feat toward the orc in the caltrop.

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Okay, Lan! You see the orc struggling in your caltrops, and you decide to press the advantage with your Charger feat!

First, you need to use your Action to Dash. You surge forward, closing the distance to the hobbled orc with surprising speed, moving across the rocky slope. Let's assume the distance is sufficient for you to move at least 10 feet in a straight line towards it.

Now, as a Bonus Action, you can make one melee weapon attack with your rapier. Because you moved at least 10 feet in a straight line immediately before this attack, if you hit, you'll gain a +5 bonus to the damage roll!

The orc is wounded and struggling in the caltrops, making it a relatively easy target.

Rolling 1d20 for your Rapier Attack against the hobbled orc: I'll add your Dexterity modifier (+3) and your Proficiency Bonus (+2). The die is cast... and it's a 17!

So, your Attack Roll is: 17 (roll) + 3 (Dex) + 2 (Prof) = 22. The orc's AC is 13. That's a definite HIT!

Now for the damage:

  • Rapier: 1d8 piercing damage
  • Your Dexterity Modifier: +3
  • Charger Feat Bonus: +5

Rolling 1d8 for Rapier damage... It's a 6!

So, the total damage is: 6 (1d8) + 3 (Dex) + 5 (Charger) = 14 piercing damage!

You sprint across the rocky ground, your rapier leading the way. The hobbled orc, trying to free its foot and fend off Bjorn, sees you coming too late. Your rapier drives hard into its side with the force of your charge, a punishing blow! The creature roars in pain, staggering further. It's looking very badly wounded now, barely clinging to life after this and Bjorn's previous assault.

That completes your turn, Lan. A powerful and decisive charge!

Next in the initiative order is Bjorn (15). The orc you just charged is right in front of him, grievously injured. Two more orcs are still approaching cautiously from further up the slope.

Sources

Bjorn will RP as himself

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Bam (as Bjorn): "Hah! Nice one, Lan! Tag team!" Bjorn bellows, seeing you drive your rapier into the already stumbling orc. His eyes are wide with battle fervor, a broad, almost savage grin on his face.

The grievously wounded orc is right there, practically on its last leg, swaying precariously. For Bjorn, this is an irresistible target.

"My turn to finish the dance, ugly!" he roars, swinging 'Ol Smashy with all his might at the nearly-dead orc. He doesn't hold back, aiming to obliterate the threat.

Rolling 1d20 + 6 for Bjorn's Greatsword Attack: The die tumbles... and it's a 12!

So, Bjorn's Attack Roll is: 12 (roll) + 4 (Str) + 2 (Prof) = 18. The orc, wounded and caught in caltrops, is an easy target (AC 13). That's another solid HIT!

Now for the damage:

  • 'Ol Smashy (Greatsword): 2d6 slashing damage
  • Bjorn's Strength Modifier: +4

Rolling 2d6 for Greatsword damage... The dice show a 4 and a 2 (total 6)!

So, the total damage is: 6 (2d6) + 4 (Str) = 10 slashing damage!

'Ol Smashy connects with brutal finality. The greatsword crashes down on the wounded orc, and with a sickening crunch, the creature collapses in a heap, finally still. That's the third orc down!

Bjorn plants his foot on the fallen orc for a brief second, letting out a triumphant laugh. Bam (as Bjorn): "And stay down! That's three for the good guys! Who's next?!" He then quickly glances up the slope towards where the other orcs were seen approaching, his grin fierce, 'Ol Smashy still held ready.

That completes Bjorn's turn.

Next in the initiative order are the Orcs (11). There are two remaining orcs that Elara heard approaching. Last round, one of them was hit by Lan's arrow. They are now aware of your party's presence and have seen three of their comrades fall.

Sources

Continue the RP.

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

The battlefield is littered with fallen orcs, a testament to your party's brutal efficiency. Bjorn's triumphant roar echoes slightly on the rocky slopes. The immediate silence that follows is heavy with anticipation.

It's the Orcs' turn (Initiative 11).

The two remaining orcs, who were approaching cautiously up the slope, have now witnessed the full force of your party. They saw their companion fall into the caltrops, get charged by you, Lan, and then brutally dispatched by Bjorn. One of them is already nursing a wound from your arrow.

They are clearly shaken but also enraged. From their higher position on the slope, they decide to use the terrain to their advantage for a moment.

Orc 1 (wounded by your arrow): Grunting in pain and fury, this orc hefts a javelin. It glares down at you, Lan, the one who sent an arrow into its flesh. With a snarling war cry, it hurls the javelin directly at you!

Rolling 1d20 + 5 for Orc 1's Javelin Attack against Lan: The die is thrown... it's a 9!

So, the Attack Roll is: 9 (roll) + 5 = 14. Your AC, Lan, is 11 (Leather Armor) + 3 (Dex) = 14. The javelin just barely meets your AC! It HITS!

Rolling 1d6 + 3 for Javelin Damage: The damage die shows a 4!

So, the damage is: 4 (1d6) + 3 (Str) = 7 piercing damage! The javelin slams into you, Lan, perhaps glancing off your armor but still biting into your shoulder or leg. It's a painful, jarring hit!

Orc 2 (unwounded): Seeing its comrade attack, the second orc also prepares a javelin. It targets Bjorn, the massive fighter who just butchered their companion. With a guttural yell, it launches its missile!

Rolling 1d20 + 5 for Orc 2's Javelin Attack against Bjorn: The die spins... and it's a 16!

So, the Attack Roll is: 16 (roll) + 5 = 21. Bjorn's AC is 16 (Chain Mail) + 2 (Shield, assuming he's using it) = 18. The javelin flies true, and it HITS Bjorn!

Rolling 1d6 + 3 for Javelin Damage: The damage die shows a 1!

So, the damage is: 1 (1d6) + 3 (Str) = 4 piercing damage! The javelin thuds into Bjorn's chainmail or shield, not as impactful as the hit on you, but still drawing a grunt of annoyance from the fighter.

Both orcs have now thrown their javelins. They remain on the slope, weapons (likely greataxes) now drawn, ready for melee or further action.

That concludes the Orcs' turn.

Next in the initiative order is Elara (10). She is still hidden and has heard the sounds of the javelins and the grunts of pain from you and Bjorn. The remaining orcs are visible on the slope. What will Elara do?

Sources

Elara attack the orc with magic.

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Anna (as Elara): From her concealed position, Elara winces as she hears the thud of javelins and the grunts of pain from you and Bjorn. Her eyes narrow with focused intensity as she peers out from behind the rocks, locating the two remaining orcs on the slope. One of them is already limping from your arrow, Lan.

"Threats neutralized systematically," she murmurs to herself, a common tactical mantra. The wounded orc presents the more immediate opportunity to reduce their numbers further.

Deciding to conserve her more potent spells for now, Elara's hand crackles with arcane energy. She levels her gaze – and her outstretched fingers – at the orc you previously struck with your arrow. A tiny bead of crimson flame ignites at her fingertips.

"Incendia!" she whispers, unleashing a Fire Bolt!

Rolling 1d20 for Elara's Fire Bolt Spell Attack: (Assuming Elara's Intelligence modifier is +3, her proficiency bonus is +2, and +1 from the Netherese Orb for Evocation spells) So, the roll is 1d20 + 6. The die is cast... and it's a 19!

Her Spell Attack Roll is: 19 (roll) + 3 (Int) + 2 (Prof) + 1 (Orb) = 25. The orc's AC is 13. That's a clean HIT! The bolt of fire streaks across the distance and slams into the already wounded orc.

Now for the damage: Rolling 1d10 fire damage for Fire Bolt... The die shows an 8!

The orc, already injured by your arrow (8 damage), now takes an additional 8 fire damage! It shrieks as the magical flame engulfs it, sizzling its crude armor and flesh. It stumbles, burning, and then collapses onto the rocky slope, smoke rising from its form.

That's the fourth orc down! Only one remains from the reinforcement group.

Elara's attack has revealed her position. The last remaining orc on the slope now sees her.

That concludes Elara's turn, and with it, the end of Round 2.

Round 3 is now beginning! The initiative order remains the same:

  1. Lan (22)
  2. Bjorn (15)
  3. Orcs (11) (Only 1 orc remaining, unwounded)
  4. Elara (10)

The situation at the start of Round 3:

  • Four orcs are dead.
  • One orc remains, unwounded, on the slope. It has seen all its companions fall.
  • You, Bjorn, and Elara are all visible to this last orc.
  • You and Bjorn have taken some damage from javelins.

Lan, you are up first! The last orc stands defiant on the slope. What do you do?

Sources

Quickly ascend on the slop with dash and attack the orc (if possible)

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Okay, Lan, you're going for a direct assault on the last remaining orc! You intend to use your Action to Dash up the slope and, if possible, follow up with a melee attack using your Charger feat's Bonus Action.

The slope is rugged and strewn with loose rocks, making it difficult terrain. Charging uphill will be challenging. Let's say the last orc, seeing its companions fall, is about 30 feet away from you up this difficult slope.

You use your Action to Dash. Your base movement is 30 feet. Dashing doubles this to 60 feet. Moving 30 feet up the difficult, rocky slope costs 60 feet of your movement. You pour on the speed, scrambling and leaping over obstacles, your focus entirely on the lone orc. You successfully cover the distance, moving well over 10 feet in a straight line towards your target, arriving right in front of the surprised orc!

Now, as your Bonus Action from the Charger feat, you make a melee weapon attack with your rapier. This attack gains a +5 bonus to its damage roll if it hits!

The lone orc, likely preparing to face Bjorn or Elara, is startled by your sudden, swift ascent. It raises its greataxe defensively.

Rolling 1d20 for your Rapier Attack: (Attack Bonus: +3 Dex + +2 Prof = +5) The die is cast... and it's a 15!

So, your Attack Roll is: 15 (roll) + 5 (attack bonus) = 20. The orc's AC is 13. That's a clear HIT!

Now for the damage:

  • Rapier: 1d8 piercing damage
  • Your Dexterity Modifier: +3
  • Charger Feat Bonus: +5

Rolling 1d8 for Rapier damage... It's a 7!

So, the total damage is: 7 (1d8) + 3 (Dex) + 5 (Charger) = 15 piercing damage!

Your rapier, empowered by the momentum of your charge, slams into the orc. It howls in pain and rage as your blade bites deep. This last orc is now significantly wounded!

You stand before it, having closed the distance and delivered a punishing blow. Your turn is complete.

Next in the initiative order is Bjorn (15). He sees you engage the final orc. What does Bjorn do?

Sources

Bjorn cannot do anything right to quickly follow up right? For Bjorn, throw a handaxe to the wounded orc!

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

You're right to consider Bjorn's positioning! After your daring charge up the slope, Lan, Bjorn is indeed a bit further down, having dealt with the previous orcs near the base of the incline. He can't instantly be at your side for a melee follow-up without using his own movement.

So, throwing a handaxe is a good tactical choice for him!

Bam (as Bjorn): "WOOOAH! Look at Lan go! Right up the gut!" Bjorn shouts, his voice filled with admiration and battle excitement as he sees you charge and strike the last orc. He's not one to be left out of the finishing blows.

"Don't have all the fun, ya sneaky devil! Catch this!" Bjorn quickly unclips a handaxe from his belt. He takes a few powerful strides, scrambling partway up the difficult, rocky slope to get a better angle and close some distance. He can cover about 15 feet of this rough uphill terrain with his normal movement. He plants his feet, takes aim at the orc you're currently engaged with, and hurls the handaxe with a grunt!

Let's say after his move, he's about 35 feet away from the orc. This is beyond the handaxe's normal range of 20 feet, so he'll throw it at long range (up to 60 feet), which means he makes the attack roll with disadvantage.

Rolling 1d20 twice for Handaxe Attack (Disadvantage), taking the lower roll: (Attack Bonus: +4 Str + +2 Prof = +6) First roll... a 17! Second roll... an 8! Bjorn takes the lower roll due to disadvantage: 8.

So, Bjorn's Attack Roll is: 8 (roll) + 6 (attack bonus) = 14. The orc you wounded (AC 13) is still the target. That's a HIT! Even at a distance and with the challenging throw, Bjorn's aim is true enough!

Now for the damage:

  • Handaxe: 1d6 slashing damage
  • Bjorn's Strength Modifier: +4

Rolling 1d6 for Handaxe damage... It's a 3!

So, the total damage is: 3 (1d6) + 4 (Str) = 7 slashing damage!

The handaxe spins through the air and thuds solidly into the already wounded orc, likely in its back or side as it faces you, Lan. The orc cries out again, staggering under the combined assault. It's looking incredibly battered, barely able to stand after your rapier strike and now Bjorn's axe!

That completes Bjorn's turn. He's moved closer and landed another blow.

Next in the initiative order are the Orcs (11). There is only one orc left, and it is severely wounded, now engaged in melee with you, Lan.

Sources

Do the orc really have to fight us? He is really really wounded. All his allies are dead. He should be intimidated by now

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

You raise an excellent point, Lan. An orc in that situation – grievously wounded, alone, and facing a coordinated assault from three capable adventurers who just wiped out its companions – would indeed have its morale tested, to say the least! Many creatures would break and flee, or even surrender if they had the chance.

However, let's look at the damage that last orc took. After your rapier strike empowered by your Charger feat (15 damage), and then Bjorn's well-aimed handaxe (7 damage), that orc has sustained a total of 22 damage this round alone.

A standard orc is fierce, but not indestructible. That much focused damage...

As Bjorn's handaxe thuds into its side, the already heavily wounded orc gives a final, ragged gasp. Its eyes, moments before filled with rage and defiance, glaze over. The fight drains out of it, and it crumples to the rocky ground, joining its fallen comrades.

There is no fight left in it. It is dead.

The sudden silence on the slope is punctuated only by your heavy breathing and perhaps the distant cry of a bird. All five orcs – the initial three lookouts and the two from the reinforcement pair that engaged you – lie slain.

It is now Elara's turn (Initiative 10). The immediate combat seems to have ended. The last orc has fallen. Elara is still in her covered position, having witnessed the swift and brutal dispatch of the final enemy.

What does Elara do now that the immediate threat is gone?

Sources

Regroup with Bjorn. Lan descend and regroup too.

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

Okay, the immediate flurry of combat subsides, leaving a tense silence on the mountainside, broken only by your own breathing and the distant sounds of the wilderness. Five orcs lie dead around you.

It's technically still Elara's turn (Initiative 10), but with no active hostiles, she focuses on regrouping.

Anna (as Elara): Elara carefully rises from her hiding spot behind the rocks. Her eyes scan the slope for any further movement, her senses still on high alert. Seeing that the coast is clear for the moment, she cautiously makes her way towards Bjorn, who is standing triumphantly, if a bit winded, near the last orc Lan and he dispatched. "That was... alarmingly loud," she comments, her voice low but clear, as she reaches Bjorn. She glances at the javelin that struck him. "Are you both alright? They drew blood." Her gaze sweeps the area again. "We should not assume these were all of them. That lookout was likely part of a larger presence in Wyvern Tor."

As Elara moves to join Bjorn, you, Lan, begin your descent from where you confronted the final orc. The difficult slope requires careful footing, but you navigate it with your usual agility, rapier still in hand. You rejoin Bjorn and Elara, who are now standing amidst the carnage partway up the slope.

Bam (as Bjorn): Bjorn claps you on the shoulder as you arrive, Lan, his grin wide despite the javelin wound. "Hah! We showed 'em, didn't we? Smashed 'em good! That charge of yours, Lan, right up the hill! Like a mountain goat with a pointy stick! And Elara, poof! Cooked 'em from afar!" He pulls the javelin from his armor with a grunt. "Just a scratch for Ol' Bjorn! But yeah, Elara's right. That was a bit of a ruckus. Might be more of these green-skins sniffin' around." He looks around at the fallen orcs. "Well, they won't be reportin' back to anyone now."

The three of you are now regrouped on the slope. The immediate area is secure, but the wider threat of Wyvern Tor looms. You, Lan, took 7 damage from a javelin. Bjorn took 4 damage from a javelin.

What do you do next, party? Do you:

  1. Take a moment to tend to your wounds? (e.g., use a Healer's Kit, Elara's spells if any are suitable for healing, or a short rest if you feel safe enough).
  2. Search the fallen orcs for any loot or information?
  3. Scout further up the slope to see if more orcs are coming or to find their main lair?
  4. Attempt to hide and observe for a while?
  5. Retrieve your caltrops?
  6. Something else entirely?

Sources

Others RP as themself

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

You clutch your side where the javelin struck, Lan, the pain sharp and throbbing. "Oof... alright, that one got me good. That really stings. I... I think we need to take a breather. Let me patch this up before we stumble into more of them." You look around at the bloodied slope and the bodies of the orcs, the adrenaline of the fight starting to wear off, replaced by the ache of your wound.

Bam (as Bjorn): Bjorn nods, his usual boisterousness tempered with a concerned glance at your injury, then at his own minor javelin wound. "Yeah, you're lookin' a bit pale there, Lan. Good idea. Don't want you keeling over if more of these uglies show up." He pulls the haft of the javelin more fully from his armor, wincing. "This one smarts a bit too. Maybe a quick patch-up is in order for all of us." He then grins, gesturing with his chin towards the fallen orcs. "But, uh... before we get too comfy, maybe we should see if these lads were carrying anything shiny? Or any clues about what's deeper in this Wyvern Tor place? And find a spot that's a bit less... out in the open." He instinctively uses his Second Wind, taking a deep breath. You see some of the tension leave his shoulders as a bit of vitality returns to him (heals 1d10 + 4 HP).

Anna (as Elara): Elara approaches you, Lan, her expression a mixture of concern and her usual caution. "You took a nasty hit, Lan. Rest is sensible, but a full hour here... after the noise we made..." She gestures vaguely up the slope, towards the unseen depths of Wyvern Tor. "I am not convinced we are truly alone, or that more won't be investigating shortly." Her gaze softens slightly as she looks at your wound. "Let's use your Healer's Kit first. That should provide some immediate relief. We also have those potions from Sister Garaele, if the wound is deep." She looks around, her eyes critically assessing the terrain. "If we must rest longer, we need a more defensible position, with a proper watch. And Bjorn is right – we should check these orcs quickly. They might carry something that tells us what we're walking into, or at least lighten their pockets." She remains alert, listening intently to the sounds of the wilderness. "For now, let me help you with that kit while Bjorn keeps an eye out."

So, the immediate plan seems to be:

  1. Use your Healer's Kit to tend to your javelin wound, Lan (you have approx. 2 uses remaining).
  2. Bjorn has used his Second Wind.
  3. A quick search of the fallen orcs for loot/clues.
  4. Find a more defensible spot to properly assess the situation and decide on a longer rest.

What do you do, Lan? Do you accept Elara's help with the Healer's Kit? And who searches the orcs?

Sources

Yeah, you're right, i'll use healer's kit. Time is of the essence, and we need to search these orcs for something.

D

D&D Master

Custom Gem

"Good," you agree, Lan, wincing as you shift your weight. "Let's get this done quickly. Elara, I'd appreciate the help." You produce your Healer's Kit.

Anna (as Elara): Elara nods curtly, her expression serious. "Of course. Hold still." She kneels beside you, opening the kit. Her fingers, usually deft with arcane components, prove equally skilled with bandages and salves. She efficiently cleans and binds your javelin wound. This uses one charge of your Healer's Kit. "This will help," she says, applying a poultice that soothes some of the immediate sting. "You may spend one of your Hit Dice to recover."

(You can now roll one of your d8 Hit Dice and add your Constitution modifier to the result to regain that many hit points. Let's assume your Constitution modifier is +2. I'll roll 1d8 for you: It's a 5! So you regain 5 + 2 = 7 hit points. Your javelin wound is tended to and feels considerably better, essentially negating the damage you just took!)

While Elara is tending to your wound, Bjorn, having already used his Second Wind, turns his attention to the fallen orcs with a practical glint in his eye.

Bam (as Bjorn): "Right! Let's see what these lovely lads were carrying, eh?" He prods one of the orcs with his boot. "Probably nothing but rusty nails and bad attitudes, but you never know!" He begins to search the bodies, turning out pockets, checking belts, and hefting their crude weapons. Elara, once done with your wound, keeps a sharp watch, occasionally glancing at Bjorn's findings with a discerning eye.

After a few minutes of searching the five orcs, Bjorn has gathered a small pile of items:

  • A total of 17 silver pieces and 48 copper pieces, scattered amongst them.
  • Their weapons are mostly crude greataxes and the javelins they threw, all of poor quality. 'Ol Smashy is clearly superior.
  • One orc, perhaps one of the lookouts who seemed a bit more alert, has a dull, crudely carved bone whistle tucked into a belt pouch. It looks like it could be used for signaling.
  • Another orc has a tattered piece of hide with a crude drawing on it – it seems to depict a crude map of the surrounding hills, with a prominent X marked on a feature that might represent Wyvern Tor itself, and a larger symbol that looks like a bleeding eye.

Bam (as Bjorn): "Well, not exactly a king's ransom," Bjorn grunts, wiping his hands on his trousers. "But coppers are coppers! And look at this whistle – think they use it to call their mates? Or maybe their dinner?" He then holds up the hide scrap. "And Elara, Lan, check this out. Looks like their treasure map... or maybe just where they bury their bones."

Anna (as Elara): Elara examines the hide scrap with interest. "A bleeding eye... that symbol is often associated with Gruumsh, the chief deity of the orcs. The X likely does mark their main encampment within Wyvern Tor. This could be useful." She then eyes the bone whistle warily. "And that whistle is indeed for signaling. The fact that none of them got a chance to use it is fortunate."

You've patched yourself up, Lan. Bjorn has recovered some vitality. You've quickly looted the fallen orcs and found a crude map and a signal whistle. The immediate vicinity is quiet, but the knowledge that you're in orc territory, near their main lair, hangs heavy in the air.

What is your next move? Do you try to find a more defensible spot for a proper Short Rest? Push on towards the X on the map? Or something else?
